section.title: Storing messages on the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS)
section.para: Version 5.33.7 of &abbrev; can send plain-text log files to the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS), allowing you to store your log data on a distributed, scalable file system. This is especially useful if you have huge amount of log messages that would be difficult to store otherwise, or if you want to process your messages using Hadoop tools (for example, Apache Pig).
Note the following limitations when using the &abbrev; hdfs destination:

listitem.para: The hdfs destination is only supported on the Linux platform.
Since &abbrev; uses the official Java HDFS client, the hdfs destination has significant memory usage (about 400MB).
The &abbrev; application always creates a new file if the previous has been closed. Appending data to existing files is not supported.

procedure.title: Prerequisites
procedure.para: To send messages from &abbrev; to HDFS, complete the following steps.

step.para: Download and install the Java Runtime Environment (JRE), 1.7 (or newer). The &abbrev; hdfs destination is tested and supported when using the Oracle implementation of Java. Other implementations are untested and unsupported, they may or may not work as expected.
Download the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) libraries (version 2.x) from http://hadoop.apache.org/releases.html.

Extract the HDFS libraries into a temporary directory, then copy the following .jar files into a directory (for example, /opt/hadoop/lib/) where &abbrev; can access them. You must specify this directory in the &abbrev; configuration file. The files are located in the various lib directories under the share/hadoop/ directory of the Hadoop release package.

Note that the version numbers in the filenames can be different in the various Hadoop releases: commons-cli-1.2.jarcommons-configuration-1.6.jarcommons-logging-1.1.3.jarhadoop-auth-2.6.0.jarhadoop-hdfs-2.6.0.jarlog4j-1.2.17.jarslf4j-api-1.7.5.jarcommons-collections-3.2.1.jarcommons-lang-2.6.jarguava-11.0.2.jarhadoop-common-2.6.0.jarhtrace-core-3.0.4.jarprotobuf-java-2.5.0.jarslf4j-log4j12-1.7.5.jar

procedure.title: How &abbrev; interacts with HDFS
procedure.para: The &abbrev; application sends the log messages to the official HDFS client library, which forwards the data to the HDFS nodes. The way how &abbrev; interacts with HDFS is described in the following steps.

step.para: After &abbrev; is started and the first message arrives to the hdfs destination, the hdfs destination tries to connect to the HDFS NameNode. If the connection fails, &abbrev; will repeatedly attempt to connect again after the period set in time-reopen() expires.

&abbrev; creates the destination file (using the filename set in the &abbrev; configuration file, with a UUID suffix to make it unique, for example, /usr/hadoop/logfile.txt.3dc1c59e-ab3b-4b71-9e81-93db477ed9d9) and writes the message into the file. After the file is created, &abbrev; will write all incoming messages into e hdfs destination.

If the HDFS client returns an error, &abbrev; attempts to close the file, then opens a new file and repeats sending the message (trying to connect to HDFS and send the message), as set in the retries() parameter. If sending the message fails for retries() times, &abbrev; drops the message.
The &abbrev; application closes the destination file in the following cases:

listitem.para: The HDFS client returns an error.

step.para: If the file is closed and you have set an archive directory, &abbrev; moves the file to this directory. If &abbrev; cannot move the file for some reason (for example, &abbrev; cannot connect to the HDFS NameNode), the file remains at its original location, &abbrev; will not try to move it again.

section.title: hdsf destination options
section.para: The hdfs destination stores the log messages in files on the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS). The hdfs destination has the following options. Some of these options are directly used by the Java code underlying the hdfs destination, therefore these options must be specified in the following format:
For example, option("hdfs-uri", "hdfs://10.140.32.80:8020"). The exact format to use is indicated in the description of the option.
The following options are required: class-path(), class-name(), hdfs-file(), hdfs-uri(). Note that to use hdfs, you must add the following line to the beginning of your &abbrev; configuration:

simplesect.para: For the hdfs destination, use this option as class-name("org.syslog_ng.hdfs.HdfsDestination").

For the hdfs destination, include the path to the directory where you copied the required libraries (see ), for example, class-path("/opt/syslog-ng/lib/syslog-ng/java-modules/*.jar:/opt/hadoop/libs/*.jar").

simplesect.title: hdfs-archive-dir()
simplesect.para: Description: The path where &abbrev; will move the closed log files. If &abbrev; cannot move the file for some reason (for example, &abbrev; cannot connect to the HDFS NameNode), the file remains at its original location. For example, option("hdfs-archive-dir", "/usr/hdfs/archive/mylogfile.txt").

simplesect.title: hdfs-file()
simplesect.para: Description: The path and name of the log file. For example, option("hdfs-file", "/usr/hdfs/mylogfile.txt").

simplesect.title: hdfs-max-filename-length()
simplesect.para: Description: The maximum length of the filename. This filename (including the UUID that &abbrev; appends to it) cannot be longer than what the file system permits. If the filename is longer than the value of hdfs-max-filename-length, &abbrev; will automatically truncate the filename. For example, option("hdfs-max-filename-length", "255").

simplesect.title: hdfs-resources()
simplesect.para: Description: The list of Hadoop resources to load, separated by semicolons. For example, option("hdfs-resources", "/home/user/hadoop/core-site.xml;/home/user/hadoop/hdfs-site.xml").

simplesect.title: hdfs-uri()
simplesect.para: Description: The URI of the HDFS NameNode in address:port format. The address of the node can be IPv4 or IPv6. For example, option("hdfs-uri", "hdfs://10.140.32.80:8020").
